toc.value: Nested items, added gap space, and item wrapping
Do's and don'ts for implementing a list

mdx:
# List The list component organizes related items or data into a vertical, scannable format. ## Overview The list component presents structured content which can include details such as text, icons, and actions, in a vertical arrangement. With improved readability letting readers quickly scan the content and compare relevant details. ### Resources Deep dive into implementation details and access the Nimbus design library. [W3C: Lists](https://www.w3.org/WAI/tutorials/page-structure/content/#lists) [Chakra UI: List](https://chakra-ui.com/docs/components/list) ## Variables Get familiar with the features. ### Basic options #### Vertical lists Vertical lists can function differently based on need. Using bullet points, numbered lists, and icons or emojis will help users understand the information differently as needed. ```jsx-live const App = () => (
    Red pandas Pangolins Opossums Aye-ayes Okapi
    Boil water Add pasta Wait patiently to cook Remove and drain pasta Add final ingredients and serve
Reading a book Talking to a friend Going for a walk Doomscrolling Not eating a treat ) ``` #### Alignment List items are aligned to the left, center and the right. Choose what suits the information to be shown based on language and data. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( Left
    Red pandas Pangolins Opossums Aye-ayes Okapi
Center
    Red pandas Pangolins Opossums Aye-ayes Okapi
Right
    Red pandas Pangolins Opossums Aye-ayes Okapi
) ``` #### Nested items, added gap space, and item wrapping When nesting related items, maintain proper spacing and wrapping to keep the structure intact. Avoid long lines of text; if necessary, rephrase to make it shorter or use body text instead of bullet points, which should be reserved for concise information. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( Nested items
    Password requirements:
      8 characters and 3 numbers One special character (!@#$%^&*)
    Name and email requirements
      Validation process
Gap space
    Password requirements:
      8 characters and 3 numbers One special character (!@#$%^&*)
    Name and email requirements
      Validation process
Item wrapping
    Password requirements:
      8 characters and 3 numbers One special character (!@#$%^&*)
    Name and email requirements
      Validation process
) ``` ## Guidelines List guidelines aim to provide users the best experience when understanding information that is being conveyed through the interface. ### Best Practices - **Consistency in content:** Ensure all items within a single list adhere to the same content structure (e.g., if one item has an icon and metadata, all items should). - **Clear hierarchy:** Use typography, indentation, and visual separators to establish a clear hierarchy between list items and their sub-elements. - **Easy scanning:** Prioritize short, primary information at the beginning of each list item to enable quick scanning. - **Interactivity:** Clearly distinguish interactive list items (tappable/clickable) from static, informational ones using visual cues like hover states and pointers. - **State management:** Define consistent visual states for list items, including default, hover, focused, selected, and disabled. - **Grouping:** Use dividers, headers, or subtle visual spacing to group related items within a long list (e.g., grouping customers by status or date). - **Limited information:** Avoid cramming too much detail into a single list item; use secondary detail panels, cards, or dedicated pages for complex information. ### Usage Lists are fundamental UI components used to display a series of related items, allowing users to quickly scan, organize, and interact with structured data or options. > [!TIP]\ > When to use - **Navigation menus:** For primary or secondary menus where items are primarily text links. - **Short metadata/tasks:** For displaying a history log, task list, or brief metadata where the vertical format is optimal for chronological or simple item tracking. - **Structured options:** To present settings, filters, or menu choices where hierarchy and text are the main content. > [!CAUTION]\ > When not to use - **Image-heavy content:** For displaying a collection where the visual preview (e.g., product image) is the most critical element. - **Wide data sets:** When the content requires many columns of data that won't fit on a single line, even on a large screen. - **Complex data comparison:** When the user needs to compare many different data points across items, use a data table instead. ### Do's and don'ts for implementing a list > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > - Ensure adequate padding and spacing to clearly separate each list item. > - Provide clear feedback when an item is selected or activated. > - Use semantic HTML (`
    `, `
      `, `
    1. `) to convey structure to assistive technologies. > - Allow content within the list item to truncate gracefully, revealing the full text via a tooltip or expansion interactive. > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > - Don't use generic links like "Click here"; make the entire interactive item text descriptive. > - Don't mix vastly different content structures or types of items in one list. > - Don't neglect a strategy for empty states (what happens when the list has no items?). > - Don't use low-contrast text for critical list item details. ### Props ### Accessibility Accessibility ensures that digital content and functionality are usable by everyone, including people with disabilities, by addressing visual, auditory, cognitive, and physical limitations. ```jsx-live const App = () => (
        Password requirements:
          8 characters and 3 numbers One special character (!@#$%^&*)
        Name and email requirements
          Validation process
      ) ``` ### Accessibility Standards - **Keyboard navigation:** Ensure all interactive list items are navigable using the Tab key and fully operable using the Enter or Spacebar keys. - **ARIA roles:** Use semantic HTML (`
        `, `
          `) when possible. For custom interactive lists, use appropriate ARIA roles (e.g., `role="listbox"`, `role="option"`) to define the component's structure. - **Focus indicators:** Provide a strong, clear visual focus indicator on the entire list item when it is being accessed via the keyboard. - **Text alternatives:** Ensure any icons or custom elements within the list item have appropriate aria-label or descriptive text. - **Reading order:** The programmatic reading order must logically match the visual vertical order.
